item.title: How to Use GitHub Copilot Agent to Build a Modern Blazor App
item.description:
Get a subscription and improve your career: https://courses.devs.school
üöÄ How to Build a Modern Blazor App Using GitHub Copilot Agent
In this video, discover how to harness the full potential of GitHub Copilot Agent to create a complete and professional-looking Blazor web app‚Äîfrom scratch, using natural language only! Learn to apply design patterns, modularize logic, fix bugs, and even build dynamic UIs, all guided by AI.
üîß Whether you're a beginner or an experienced dev, this video will show you the future of software development‚Äîcoding by conversation.
‚è±Ô∏è Timestamps
00:00 ‚Äì What if coding was just a conversation? 00:16 ‚Äì From password method to scalable system 00:22 ‚Äì Architecture with AI: factory pattern & class libraries 00:31 ‚Äì Live coding with GitHub Copilot 01:15 ‚Äì What is Copilot Agent? 02:01 ‚Äì Creating the project via terminal + first AI prompts 03:13 ‚Äì Explaining code with AI 05:51 ‚Äì Fixing bugs using quick actions 08:14 ‚Äì Reviewing and commenting code with Copilot 10:01 ‚Äì Generating documentation & unit tests 12:11 ‚Äì Installing dependencies through the terminal with AI 13:30 ‚Äì Using Inline Chat in the code editor & terminal 16:10 ‚Äì Exploring the dedicated Chat Window 17:03 ‚Äì Understanding Ask, Edit, and Agent modes 18:00 ‚Äì Applying design patterns using AI 21:05 ‚Äì Editing multiple files and refactoring with natural language 26:00 ‚Äì Building a full Blazor web app with Copilot Agent 30:00 ‚Äì Enhancing UI with Bootstrap Icons & Services 32:00 ‚Äì Final result: A complete Blazor app with password generation, validation & history

item.title: Theory in practice: Why Treating Metadata as Relations Pays Off
item.description: Underpinning relational databases you find a very powerful principle: all your information should be represented as attributes drawn from domains in relations(Pascal 2020). This is Codd‚Äôs Information Principle #1. This principle isn‚Äôt just fluffy theory: it can lead to very concrete wins in how we design, query, and maintain systems.1 A practical case: Dependencies for Security Policies This is clearly a metadata question: Which other database objects does this view depend on?

item.title: The Post-Developer Era ‚Ä¢ Josh W. Comeau
item.description: When OpenAI released GPT-4 back in March 2023, they kickstarted the AI revolution. The consensus online was that front-end development jobs would be totally eliminated within a year or two.Well, it‚Äôs been more than two years since then, and I thought it was worth revisiting some of those early predictions, and seeing if we can glean any insights about where things are headed.

item.title: Josh Duff | The joy of inventory software
item.description: The purpose of inventory software is to take something about the world and represent it in a database so the people who care (like the people who own the things, or the people responsible for selling them) can look it up easily.

item.title: Hallucinations in LLMs: A Side Effect of Being Trained to Be Right?
item.description: I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about hallucinations in large language models lately, and I have a theory: they‚Äôre not just a quirk of imperfect training data or model size. They might actually be caused by instruction tuning - specifically, by how we train these models to always provide correct answers.

item.title: A custom 404 page in Blazor Web Apps
item.description: Sometimes you want to have a custom 404 page - and since .NET 8 and "Blazor WebApps" the <NotFound> tag of the Router doesn't work anymore, so let's create a custom page for that.
